pros: Very strong tuition reimbursement programs (start instantly on hire) 403b contributions matching is a perk (when it's available) Tuitions for dependents is also good (if you can last 3 years) Some people are very friendly

Pay is, of course, lower since they are a "nonprofit" but they expect you to embrace their tuition benefits to make up the money that's not in your pocket. There's also specifically in the marketing department a weird sense of community, but also hierarchy. SLU is very political, and this sometimes gets in the way of the work they do. You will either love this or hate this, personally working here is not for me.

job_title: Program Coordinator in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Stable employment, clean location, consistent hours, full time
cons: The pay was terrible. We're underpaid from the start, but they don't give raises. Ever, even though we're told to consider the low pay because we'll eventually make asking. We won't. In addition, the rating system is a joke. You could work above expectations, then be told they don't give that to everyone because there's always room for improvement. I had to stop working there because I was at the top of my expertise there and went above and beyond, and still no raise whatsoever. It's a stepping stone with starter salary. That's it. They also try to sell you with the holidays, like getting all of that time paid during Thanksgiving and Christmas. Go to a different university. You're wasting your time if you think you'll have a career there.

job_title: Registered Medical Assistant in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Pay was not terrible. I met very nice easy-going patients.
cons:
This is regarding the St. Mary location.
Terrible staff and management. We had monthly meetings were people overtasked each other, and after meetings, no change was put in order, only on minor things such as cleaning or stocking bathroom, even that was a fight for coworkers to do it. Sick notices from doctors offices weren't accepted. So if your sick your sick. You take the chance to be terminated. The residents and doctors pass stomach bugs and Covid around like communion. I have been exposed and caught things on three different occasions. Management is overwhelmed and mismanaged. Due to their newness, with questions, they just as a Medical Assistant. Basics such as Autoclave maintainability can't even be answered by management. Prepare for last minute changes to the schedule daily, due to call offs etc, there for even if you go to St. Marys for your known shift, they will send you to saint Lukes right as you walk in due to someone else not showing up or calling off. Very unprofessional staff. Very cliquey, and barely anyone smiles. Hallways and work spaces are overcrowded. Long term MA's in the office do what they want, come and go as they please with no reprimand. MA's from other floors or the other side of the building will peep in on you, then go tell your immediate supervisor that you have no work to do, even though they never asked you. Supervisor will then give you more work on top of your work.

review_title: Great place to work, great atmosphere--one of the best parts of my college experience!
job_title: Reference Student Assistant in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
I worked at Pius during my first go-around as a student (2009-2013), and also in 2016 when I went back to school to finish my bachelor's. I still like to go up there to visit, and at some point I want to join the Library Associates program to have full access to books again! 

The staff are friendly, helpful, collegial, and honestly some of the kindest people I've ever met. It's a very human-centered atmosphere, and it's a great way for students to earn money and also have a chance to get some homework done if it's quiet. If you do Federal Work Study, I think it helps the library; don't quote me on that, though, because that info is definitely from my time back in 2013. 

I couldn't recommend this place more.
cons: Honestly, it was just office drudgery stuff--we were responsible for fixing the printers, scanners, etc., and the damn printers would break constantly. I hated that part. Also, it was a con how much the staff was underutilized! They absolutely love helping students, and I don't think enough students are aware of the breadth of their services.

job_title: ITS in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Good benefits.  Flexible schedules.  Nice, friendly co-workers.  Decent pay.  Great emphasis on job skills training.  Great IT network.  Wonderful campus.
cons:
Everything is "students first" (they are an academic institution) but sometimes things should take priority over that.  "Hurry up and wait" is the overall mantra.  Greater emphasis is on self-improvement and personal life, which can be a good thing, and ITS work is second.  Projects can be placed on "hold" until key personnel are available (which could be months away).

ITS Management talks the talk, but won't walk the walk.  Project management is weak.  PM Process is set up but changes on a whim.  No one is required to follow the process, not even the different ITS departments.

The perception is ITS vs the SLU Colleges (academia).  All of the different SLU colleges want to do things on their own and not have to go through ITS.  Makes for a tougher row to hoe to get things done.  Fr. Biondi needs to get the entire SLU University on the same page and doing the same thing.

Middle managers and above attend meetings with their laptops so that they can multi-task during the meeting.  What that is saying is, their work is more important than the meeting they are attending.  So some RESPECT and leave the laptop in your office.  If you have work to do, skip the meeting.

pros: The pros are very limited. You have some freedom of where you work, sometimes remotely and sometimes from a hammock on campus.  Good benefits.
cons:
As someone who worked in first ITS and then another department. The university is terrible. The management is overall poor. They make promises and then pull it out from under you. 

I was promised I would earn more than I made as a contractor prior to becoming full time, but instead I earn much less.  The management is constantly changing their minds about things so you always are playing catch up. They also love to micromanage everything. I was the SME for a very particular system on the campus and then they outsourced it to another contractor company. Their IT resources are mostly contracted through HCL and if you've ever worked with them before, they are a terrible company whose idea of good firewall rules is lock everything and fight tooth and nail to never unblock the needed traffic. 

The refuse to spend anything on their IT services and instead you deal with 15 year old hardware that you are expected to just simply make work for better or worse. 

Upper management does not listen to requests for a unified architecture and instead simply  chooses to move everything to a new data center, as if that will fix the infrastructure problems that plague the university IT.

review_title: Just told by Department Head No Chance for Advancement because of fiscal situation
job_title: Administrative in Saint Louis, MO
pros: SLU had a culture of valuing people - students, faculty, and staff when I began to work there four years ago, Their phrase, Higher Purpose, Greater Good resonated with me.  I posted it in my office..
cons: I have worked at SLU for four years. During this time, I have received three Exceeds Expectations Performance Reviews. Since the layoffs last March, I have taken on greater responsibilities, comparable to those in the next level of the organization. At the end of all of this, my hourly wage has gone up 70 cents per hour in four years.  Today the head of my department told me that (s)he can't offer me any chance for advancement, even if someone in our department leaves, because of SLU's fiscal situation. I feel very devalued.  SLU is a hypocritical disaster area. The President pontificates endlessly, while keeping the same people who were the top administrators during all of the years the fiscal crisis developed. They still have their fat paychecks and big titles, but someone like me has no chance for advancement.  Many of my direct service colleagues had their positions eliminated last March, and that continues to happen. All the folks whose positions were eliminated did was show loyalty to the University and give the students excellent service, but their positions were eliminated, while the fat cats who made the decisions who created the fiscal situation cried crocodile tears for their more modestly paid colleagues (who were now out of work) all the way to the bank.  There are days when SLU literally makes me sick.

review_title: Administrative Assistants Significantly Overutilized for "Other duties as assigned" - Not paid for it...
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
The benefits are second to none when it comes to health insurance, wellness benefits, and retirement plans. 

Tons of fully paid holidays due to the Catholic holiday calendar. 

Some colleges within the University allow you to bring your dog to work with you on a designated day of each month. 

A *lot* more flexible when it comes to raising a family while working.
cons:
"Other duties as assigned" will get you EVERY time. You will absorb the jobs of other positions in your vicinity that the University chooses not to fill (whether during a hiring freeze or otherwise) and you will not be compensated for it, but you WILL BE expected to be overworked and meeting those deadlines. 

You are also subjected to a faculty-staff caste system. They are, admittedly, working to change this dynamic by providing a program for reporting faculty abuse of staff and providing a mitigation program for said abusive behavior. 

More and more positions are being posted as salaried, instead of hourly, and they are working you after hours, and desperately needing you for this or for that when you are scheduled (with time you've earned to be out of the office).

No maternity leave whatsoever for staff positions. 

Staff positions, especially those labeled "Administrative Assistant" will be consistently overloaded with higher level requests, though not above his/her abilities -----way WAY above his/her pay grade...

cons: There weren't any pay raises as far as I can remember, but that is to be expected of part time student employment.
